dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mist shrouds the prison.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: Closed. Then the lids fly wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ASIAN MAN sits up on his cot, coming out of sleep with gasp. SHU KAI KIM is in his late 20s. With a muscled tors and shaved head meant to inspire fear. And to hide it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electrified doors slide OPEN. Shu steps out of his ce ORTEGA -- a rugged young Chicano -- steps out of a nearby cell. The two cons trade small nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CONS walk in single file. Ortega is behind Shu. Orteg speaks softly, with barely perceptible lip movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear will kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu's replies are like a ventriloquist's, as well. The tw men are running through some sort of arcane drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I'd stand in for you... But  then, believing you are weak, they'd  come for you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Right after chapel... it's  going down in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Shu and Ortega file into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the dais, the MINISTER leads a small CONVICT CHOIR.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: The cons have segregated themselves into sullen groups of black, white, and brown.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR CONS
dialogues.text: At the rear. SHU is flanked by TWO stringy CHICANOS. Orte sits behind Shu. All four stare ahead with an intense  blankness.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE SIDE
dialogues.text: Now we see what's really happening: Shu grips two sharpen spoons. The Chicanos wrap duct tape around Shu's fists -- that even if he wanted to, he couldn't let go of the kniv

dialogues.speaker: A WHITE CON
dialogues.text: In front. DUANE LINDEMAN is burly, with long blond locks, his arms decorated with SWASTIKAS. Tattooed on one cheek three black teardrops. Lindeman is surrounded by OTHERS l him. All SINGING a hymn to the Lord Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CHAPEL DOORS
dialogues.text: A disturbance out in the hall: we hear THUMPS, loud CURSI

dialogues.speaker: DUANE LINDEMAN
dialogues.text: and FRIENDS just keep on singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the Congregation turns around, to see what's  going on. The TWO CORRECTIONS OFFICERS at the rear of the Chapel venture to the door and peer out, truncheons drawn TWO WHITE INMATES spring out of opposing back row aisle s and SLAM SHUT the Chapel doors on the C.O.s -- who immedi start POUNDING on the doors with their STICKS. ONSTAGE - A hulking WHITE member of the CHOIR discreetly  moves to block the fire exit offstage.

dialogues.speaker: SHU AND ORTEGA
dialogues.text: turn back around to face what appears at first glance to a grotesque apparition:

dialogues.speaker: DUANE LINDEMAN
dialogues.text: seems to be flying from the front of the chapel toward th blond hair flowing, arms waving, a warlock... In fact, he's racing from the top of one pew-back to the  next -- and his HANDS are duct-taped, too, around not  sharpened spoons, but long, serrated blades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfuckers! Not in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIREN WAILS as Lindeman leaps at Shu -- who executes a  perfectly timed karate throw, sending Lindeman over his  shoulder to land sprawling in the aisle. Lindeman's tattooed ACCOMPLICES move to help. Ortega hold them off. Before Lindeman can right himself, Shu pins the blond Goliath. Brings a fist to Lindeman's neck, sharpene spoon pressed against the neo-Nazi's jugular. Outraged, the MINISTER claws his way through the crowd of rubbernecking cons. Shu is breathing too hard to demand that Lindeman concede But his message is clear. Now, in gasps:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill... me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead, Shu lifts the sharpened spoon away from Lindeman neck. Carefully climbs off, steps back. Lindeman lies there defeated. Then looses a startling ban SCREAM and springs, blades flashing, at Shu. They're like two snarling cats. Wrestling so furiously, w see only a blur of flesh, glint of metal. Splash of blood A RING of INMATES forms around the combatants. Some CHEER others SHOUT for the fight to stop. None dare interfere. Now the BACK DOORS virtually fly off their hinges as a HA DOZEN C.O.s in RIOT GEAR charge the Chapel. It takes all six to drag the bloody cons apart. Shu  immediately goes limp; Duane Lindeman is slack, twitching Horrified, the Minister backs off, vestments soaked in go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAB merges onto the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

dialogues.speaker: MANHATTAN ISLAND
dialogues.text: We PAN to the Brooklyn Bridge and PICK UP the CAB as it h Mannattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back seat, face pressed to the glass, is ROGER BAR A 25-year-old whose persona straddles two worlds: In his  Brooks Brothers suit he'd be welcome in any boardroom. Wi his Buddy Holly glasses and conceptually cropped hair, he someone you'd want in your band. Roger checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I give you some extra money,  have you drop me at the Courthouse  and bring my luggage to the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CABBIE turns around, at a red light. No creepier than the average New York Cabbie. He is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger smiles back. Big problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manhattan's fortress-like Criminal Courts Building. Roger climbs out of the cab, lugging a suitcase, a briefcase, a duffel bag and a garment bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a COURT OFFICER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for the court where Edward  T. Dowd is defending a Mr. Nevins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Court Officer consults the docket sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Edward Dowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Court Officer blinks at Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part 73, Room 1113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, deadpan:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Room 1113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Assistant D.A. stands before the JURY, in mid-summatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward Dowd is an inventive lawyer.  I'm sure he'd like you to believe  that the pound of pure cocaine found  in his client's home was intended  for personal, recreational use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several JURORS stifle snickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may claim that the many pounds of  baby laxative were intended to help  Mr. Nevins stay regular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More muted SOUNDS of amusement, from the gallery, as Roge ENTERS. He quietly deposits his luggage in the empty back row, then moves to the front row, behind the defense tabl Seated there is a slick, natty DEFENSE ATTORNEY. Next to is a wired and weird-looking DEFENDANT in a threadbare su the cut decades out of date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will Mr. Dowd say the defendant  weighed on his laboratory scales?  Oh, he'll think of something... But  bear in mind that you jurors control  the scales that really count -- the  scales of justice. Only you can ensure  that the defendant -- a man who sells  dangerous drugs to teenagers, for  profit...

dialogues.speaker: THE DEFENDANT
dialogues.text: winces. He's in his mid-40s, his face framed by a MANE of HAIR that hangs to his shoulders. His vintage suit accent by an embarrassingly wide and loud floral-print tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...will pay a penalty. Be wise, be  fair, and have courage. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she crosses to the Prosecution Table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ms. Jessum. Mr. Sweeney,  may I have a word with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mr. Sweeney -- the Court Officer -- confers with the J Roger leans forward. Whispers to the Defense Attorney:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger Baron. Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Defense Attorney looks mildly baffled. Regardless, Ro extends a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an honor. And a thrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what the hell: he shakes with Roger. Now the DEFENDANT turns, to see what's going on. Trying t breathe as much empathy as he can into the one syllable:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Defendant has fixed Roger with the sort of soul-pierc stare it takes many acid trips to perfect. So, delicately

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you, um, accused of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All sorts of things. How 'bout you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? N-no, I'm a lawyer, I'm here to  work with Mr. Dowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nodding at the Defense Attorney. We HEAR a POUNDING gavel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dowd, would you care to make  your closing argument?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger pats the Defendant's shoulder. Reassures:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in good hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Defendant lifts his eyebrows, as though to say "Is th so?" Turns back around. And, for some reason, he rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Confused, at first -- then mortified: omigod, that's Dowd

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD C. DOWD
dialogues.text: takes three long, crooked strides over to the Jury Box, h clasped behind his back, hair streaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian Nevins' pound of pure cocaine  was quite clearly intended for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JURORS look surprised. So does the D.A. So does BRIAN NEVINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby laxative -- dealers use it  to dilute their coke before selling  it. They can -- quadruple their  profits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NEVINS throws a jittery glance at the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and of course you can't sell  cocaine without a laboratory scale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie strikes a tone of cosmic lamentation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cocaine is evil. Selling cocaine is  evil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevins checks his mental Rolodex for a great appeals lawy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity this foolish merchant. Dislike  him if you must. But despise the  tactics the police employed to snare  Brian Nevins... Don't lose sight of  what's really on trial here -- our  basic personal freedoms, our quality  of life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Freedoms" and "life" are rendered as startling SHOUTS th make the Jurors sit up straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sublime concepts, such as "the right  of the people to be secure in their  persons, houses, papers, and effects,  against unreasonable searches and  seizures..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's delivery suggests an unholy but hard-to-dismiss h of rabbi and diva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For when we condone the bugging of  our citizens' bedrooms, when we allow  the police to enter our citizens'  homes with specious warrants, when  we invade our citizens' privacy in a  frenzied quest for a wicked white  powder, aren't we capitulating to  the evil, aren't we surrendering to  the drug? Aren't we saying cocaine  is more potent than our Constitution?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger maintains a discreet distance behind Eddie and Nevi as lawyer and client stroll down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that speech... It was beautiful.  Amazing horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tight smile) Amazing client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevins isn't sure how to respond. So he gives Eddie a qui vigorous, almost hostile hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie Dowd... Everybody should own  one.

dialogues.speaker: OMIT
dialogues.text: Nevins spins away, hops into his girlfriend's double-park Porsche. As the happy couple blasts off down the block, R draws even with Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About the mix-up back there... I,  ah, never saw your photo, I just  read every civil liberties brief you  filed in the '60s...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie distractedly nods. Then rotely sticks out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it was nice meeting ya. Gotta  get back to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes Roger a beat to realize the awful truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger Baron, Oberlin undergrad,  Michigan Law? None of this rings a  bell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Amused, now, by the absurd series of missteps:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hired me? To clerk for you? My  letter...? Top 5 percentile, Law  Review, salary is no object...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This last detail apparently jogs Eddie's memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start trudging to the subway station. Roger awkwardl lugs his suitcase, garment bag, duffel bag and briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, lemme help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several streets converge here; so do gays, yuppies, and  diehard bohemians. As Eddie and Roger emerge from the IRT station, and cross 7th Avenue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...read your Chase Manhattan bombing  case summation in the '71 Leftist  Law anthology...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie lives and works over a landmark cigar store and an  eyesore of an all-night deli. As he unlocks the downstair door, Roger takes in the seedily picturesque Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is Greenwhich Village?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie smiles. Somewhere between sarcastic and self-effaci

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Roger. You've arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts up the stairs. Roger follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balding rugs, macrame hanging things, birdcages, Salvatio Army couches. TWO leather-clad SCARECROWS pace; a teenage GIRL with blue hair squats on the floor, comforting her  SQUALLING INFANT. Then there's the slick young COUPLE in  Ralph Lauren Polo ensembles, here with a furtive STRAIGHT ARROW who scans the Wall Street Journal. A crew-cutted secretary (BILLY) types with one hand, grab the RINGING PHONE with the other. To judge by her typing telephone skills, she was hired for her capacity to manag this menagerie. Roger has struggled up the stairs, behind Eddie. Though h quickly notes the office's squalor and questionable clien what catches his eye is the trio of cracked and yellowing PHOTOGRAPHS tacked on a wall in the foyer. Eddie in his late-'60s glory days: On a dais, igniting an anti-war rally. Hugging a pair of Black Panthers outside courtroom, his face suffused with joy. In a swarm of stud activists outside a Federal courthouse, held on the shoul of the crowd like a conquering hero. As his gaze lingers on the photographs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and re-read that summation til I  knew it verbatim. You were my age  when you defended that case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie edgily pushes Roger past the photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never your age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SCARECROWS clamor for Eddie, e.g., "You gotta call my parole officer!" and "Did we get the continuance?" Eddie  ignores. Addresses his secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy -- this here's Roger, the new  assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie wheels away, answers the RINGING PHONE (grunting a  perfunctory promise into it), then gestures for Straight- Arrow and Slick Couple to come into his inner office. Rog starts to follow, but Eddie shuts his inner office door b him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to be an "assistant" or an  "associate"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger turns to see Billy tugging on her denim jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of them like "assistant," some  like "associate". Up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- How many others are there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Billy, wearing a slight smirk, bustles out the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the current one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger wistfully watches her go. OS, he HEARS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Eddie's new partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCARECROW 1 is standing a tad too close for comfort. Stil Roger is grateful for the attempt at friendliness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Well, kind of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger flinches, lets out an involuntary YELP as Scarecrow grabs his lapels, shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta call my parole officer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spruce ASSISTANT D.A. (GLENN FULTON) jauntily exits a  courtroom. Followed by a grim-faced Eddie, with Roger and CLYDE GRUNER, a sullen, street-hardened PUNK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his client) Clyde, you wait here. (to the D.A.) Glenn, got a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a minute before the Mapp hearing --  but I couldn't get you on the phone,  Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I had reasonable cause to  believe the judge might've heard of  the Fourth Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TRACK with Fulton, Eddie and Roger as they thread thro the THRONG of milling lawyers, clients, relations and cop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Gruner was caught with three  pounds of methedrine. The legality  of the search and seizure was the  only issue. The Judge refused to  exclude the evidence. No deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns a corner. So does Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not the only issue. There's  another issue, for the jury. What  about entrapment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about entrapment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fulton veers into the Men's Room. Eddie follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger enters, behind Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenn, the government sent an  undercover cop to dangle the lure of  fantastic profits before Clyde  Gruner's eyes. Anyone so sorely  tempted might succumb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger lingers at the sink as Eddie follows Fulton to the  urinals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't prosecute people because in  the abstract they might be weak.  Judge Brandeis said it best:  Entrapment is a "dirty business!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I take a simple piss without --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's voice trembles with outrage and inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see? Planting the idea of  being a criminal is just one step  away from planting the evidence!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fulton flushes. Grudgingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't heard that one before, Ed. (zips up, sighs) But I guess I'll be hearing it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger backs out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde is standing out here. Roger has nothing to say to C He goes to the water fountain for a very long sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this hour, the office is empty. As EDDIE and ROGER ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevins stopped by. It's on your desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he lopes toward his inner office:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pleaded out Clyde Gruner to five  years' probation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Score another point for truth and  justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stops, shoots Billy a "fuck you too" look. Then tur to Roger and staunchly reaffirms:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last struggle for constitutional  rights is being waged over drugs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atop his desk is a package wrapped in newspaper. Eddie te it open, revealing small bills bundled with rubber bands. he counts the cash:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're in the ring, Roger, doing  battle with Big Brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger turns away from the drug money, embarrassed and ash

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Billy is gone as well. ROGER sits in his cramped ante of an office, mechanically making notes. OS, there's a KN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'S' open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't bother looking up -- who cares which East Vill doper or Yuppie coke dealer it is? But then he hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Edward Dowd?

dialogues.speaker: TWO ORIENTAL WOMEN
dialogues.text: are in the outer office. One is college-age, assimilated. The other is in her early 40s, with the aspect of an  immigrant. A vinyl satchel is slung over her shoulder. Th younger woman has come -- reluctantly, it seems -- to  translate for the older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward Dowd, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger gets up from his desk. Hurries into the big room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Roger Baron -- Mr. Dowd's  associate. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Immigrant anxiously peers past Roger. She knows he's Edward Dowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kim needs a lawyer. Her son  stabbed a man to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In response Mrs. Kim -- who evidently understands English makes a passionate point, in a foreign tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was self-defense. In prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This clarification elicits another burst from Mrs. Kim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls) Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amends) He didn't belong there in the first  place. Eight years for a murder he  didn't commit. (adds) I'm her neighbor's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without turning away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Eddie comes striding in from his office. Waving a a cloud of pot smoke that's followed him out. He gives th women his patented reassuring smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Eddie Dowd. What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kim starts in again, rapid-fire. The Translator spew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her son didn't shoot anybody. He's  the wrong guy. You meet him, you see  he wouldn't stab a guy for fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shot a man and stabbed a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kim violently shakes her head as she chatters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't shoot anybody! Eight years  in jail! The wrong guy! A good boy.  From a fine home in Seoul, Korea.  Shu Kai Kim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kim finally quiets. The Translator takes a breath. A explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his name. Shu Kai Kim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie nods, solemnly taking all this in. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he's a wonderful boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger watches Eddie, to see where he's going. Hides his  disappointment when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't help him. You see I have  a specialty. Lawyers specialize,  Mrs. Kim, and these days I do  mostly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't bother explaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I couldn't even go see your  son without looking at the files on  his case, first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In response Mrs. Kim swings her satchel -- bulging with S files -- into Eddie's arms. It's like taking a medicine b to the chest. When he catches his breath:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over Mrs. Kim) She went to all the courthouses. She  talked to pot smokers, pill sellers...  They all speak of you, they all say  the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie can't help but puff up a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kim answers in Korean. Translator hesitates. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do cases cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger stifles a laugh. Eddie lowers Mrs. Kim's satchel to the floor and places a hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Mr. Baron and I will  review your material and get back to  you as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kim intently peers at Eddie to gauge his sincerity. boldly meets her gaze as he steers her to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for stopping by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidently convinced, Mrs. Kim makes a parting remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thanks you in advance for saving  her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie flashes one last smile, then closes the door on the women. Roger shakes his head, bemused and moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "She thanks you in advance for saving  her son."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the vinyl satchel, starts pulling out papers. Eddie feels compelled to poison the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about hard-sell, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snorts, incredulous, as he crosses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me a guy who's not somebody's  son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger looks up at this remark. Then sets down the satchel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie has re-lit his evening joint. As he settles back to enjoy it, there's Roger in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather than reach for the joint, Roger mops his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew. That was close... We almost  defended a guy who wasn't a dealer.  Who knows, might even be innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie chuckles, defensive. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a full caseload, Rog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, I forgot... We're pledged to  protect every mid-level drug dealer  in the Tri-state area. (shivers) It's an awesome responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't venerate drug dealers, Roger.  To the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...through use of informants,  eavesdropping, unreasonable search  and seizure...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right I'm right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger starts for the door. Stops. Turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just... I leave behind friends,  family, a coupla good job offers in  Chicago and in three dizzying weeks  I've helped acquit a coke dealer, a  speed dealer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I specialize, Roger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- an angel dust dealer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a kid anymore, I can't be  all over the map --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a speed manufacturer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So go take your job on Wall Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me where to work. I moved  to New York to work for Edward Dowd.  But I can't believe that Edward Dowd  has nothing better to do these days  than invoke exalted legal issues to  get off guilty little --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. You plan to be a criminal defense  attorney, know this going in:  Everybody's guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This buys Roger's silence, for two beats. Then, sadly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't've said that ten years  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs his briefcase. Starts for the door. As he swings open he HEARS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years is a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops, turns) Look -- I'm tired, I'll see you in  the morning, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie watches him walk out. Drops the joint and vengefull grinds it out on the floor. To the closed door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, now, he surveys his shabby domain and sighs, deepl As he exhales, Eddie seems to be trying to blow away all pot smoke that has clouded the room and shrouded his hear Then he shambles across the office and through the door t leads to his living quarters. We TRACK with EDDIE past a  kitchenette equipped with no labor-saving devices into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, and beyond spartan. Single bed in one corner, plai wooden bureau opposite. The only color is provided by Edd festive trial ties, casually strewn. Eddie's bedroom is n unlike a cell we saw at the beginning of the movie. Eddie stands at the window, trying to stare past the secu bars into the New York night. But all he can see is his  reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER is roused from sleep by a persistent KNOCKING. He  stumbles out of bed, staggers to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the door) We're late. Let's get going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger opens up. Eddie looks alarmingly revved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ossining Correctional Facility. Sing  Sing. Everybody's innocent there,  man... Just ask 'em...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wending north along the Hudson. ANGLE Eddie's rusty old B Riviera as it wheezes its way upstate. OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 16 Shu Kai Kim emigrated with his  family from Korea to New York...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger extracts the pertinent info from the newspaper clip in Mrs. Kim's files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim got busted at 19 for burglary.  At 20 he was convicted in the shooting  death of a young Chinese gang lord...  The prosecution claimed Kim did it  to get into "the Joe Boys"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinatown street gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim denied it. But he admitted the  gun was his, and he got life. Seems  to have been an okay prisoner for  eight years, til the... incident  with Duane Lindeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The Nazi he knifed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Roger is staring ahead now, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: The turrets and watchtowers of the Ossining Correctional  Facility loom... all too real...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO CORRECTIONS OFFICERS lead the lawyers through a secur checkpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is large and bare but for a long wooden TABLE, f chairs. Leaden light leaks through one high, barred windo Eddie and Roger, on one side of the table, anxiously wait Roger jumps at the CRUNCH of a deadbolt lock, turning. Two hefty OFFICERS enter escorting SHU, in manacles. One  pulls out the chair for Shu, the other sits him down. Edd waits for them to back out of the room and re-lock the do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Eddie Dowd. I'm a lawyer. This  here's Roger Baron -- also a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu's eyes, beady and suspicious, bore into Roger. Roger wants to smile. But he can't. He stares down at his notebook. Now Shu peruses Eddie's long hair, peculiar suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother find you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undaunted) Want to tell me what went down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very slowly) Racist asshole came at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what happened then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) I killed the motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger is now furiously scribbling notes; we can almost he him whimper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night that kid was shot to death  in Chinatown, you were... where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu doesn't answer. Eddie reaches into his jacket pocket, pulls out a pack of cigarettes. Offers one to Shu. Shu  wordlessly plucks the cigarette from his fingers, careful avoid any contact. Eddie lights it. Now Roger wills himself to look up from his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the trial, you said you were at  your apartment that night. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) That's eight years ago. Long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies his cigarette. No -- he's staring at the shack on his wrists. Stares for one, two, three beats. Gravely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie's eyes flicker: He's heard that phrase, or one quit like it, somewhere before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawyers head for Eddie's Riviera, in the visitor's lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So what would we claim? He stabbed  Duane Lindeman in self-defense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two knives taped to his hands?  Forget it, Rog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger sighs. Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I've been mugged... Guy  scared the shit out of me. You made  your point, Eddie... I'm relieved  we're not taking the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're taking the other case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight years ago. The Chinatown hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger stares, baffled, as Eddie orates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some gang punk gets wasted in front  of the tourists. The mayor pressures  the cops. The cops pressure the rival  gang -- the Joe Boys. The Joes give  up Shu Kai Kim -- the schmuck kid  from Korea who's been pestering 'em  to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think that's what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know but it makes one hell  of an opening statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they reach the Riviera, Eddie's in his all-the-world's courtroom mode; i.e., he shouts, does semaphore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We prove Shu should never have been  imprisoned in the first place, D.A.  'll back off the Lindeman charge...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawyers climb in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Easy as that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy? No... We have to find some  piece of evidence that got buried,  to reopen the sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Are you sure we want that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie shifts into gear. Pensive, now, as he steers out of the prison parking lot:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a victim, Roger. He deserves to  see the sun again, breathe the air.  He's been in prison too goddamn long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of warehouses in lower Manhattan, under the shado of the West Side Highway. Out of the drizzly darkness com the RIVIERA, headlights doused. The car GROANS to a halt. Eddie and Roger climb out. Furtively glance around... Roger follows Eddie to the fortified ENTRANCE of one of t warehouses. Eddie KNOCKS (in a pattern) on the reinforced steel door. Three sets of TUMBLERS TURN. The door opens. Filling the doorframe is the imposing silhouette of a MAN Nikes, chinos and windbreaker that must be standard issue for plainclothes cops. In a Darth Vader voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK. Then Tommy flicks ON a row of OVERHEADS, lighting long, tall aisle of gunmetal gray LOCKERS. Aisle after ai in shadow, to either side. Reverently, to Roger:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Exhibit Warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: END OF THE AISLE
dialogues.text: Tommy paces, checking his Timex. Eddie and Roger squat on the asphalt, sifting through pil of paper. Each has two large boxes to process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transcript... transcript...  exhibits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses to to contemplate a grisly photo.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHOTO
dialogues.text: A man's face, in 3/4 profile, with gaping entrance wound  above the left eye. The man is young, Asian, very dead.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: Roger hurriedly tucks the picture away. But the next item comes upon is:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The murder weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gingerly holds a sealed plastic bag sagging with the w of a handgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found four of Shu's fingerprints  on this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie impatiently glances over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you start working for the  goddam D.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie... I don't know about this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Eddie has already resumed his search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later. Roger holds a form, yellowed with age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie... What's a DD-5?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Complaint Follow-Up form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Listen: "November 5, 1980. Cecil  Stipe walked into 5th Precinct. Says  he witnessed Chin shooting, saw  suspect's picture in Post. Says Shu  Kai Kim wrong man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cecil Stipe"? Have we seen any  affadavit with that name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger looks at Eddie, slowly shakes his head. Time stops. Roger looks back down at the memo. Reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Also says he knows who killed  Kennedy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time starts again. Roger lets the memo flutter to the flo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep looking. Something'll turn up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE'S HANDS
dialogues.text: Reaching for another sheaf of documents. Rifling through pages, running his index finger down columns of text...

dialogues.speaker: END OF THE AISLE
dialogues.text: Piles of paper everywhere. By the lawyers' haggard looks, know something didn't turn up. Tommy surveys the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean-up time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie looks up, exhausted -- but scheming, still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your brother, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kept him out of the slammer and  I thank you, Dowd. But if you're not  gone before the day shift shows up,  I'm back to emptying parking meters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie surveys all this evidence, that they've been throug twice. Looks over at Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That DD-5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, the lunatic who --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cecil Stipe." Find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KITTY GREER strides down the West Village street. Kitty's 40, once cute, now simply sexy, and not apologetic about

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hangout that time forgot. Kitty finds the table where Eddie and Roger sip espresso. With studied detachment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stands. Pulls out Kitty's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger Baron, Kitty Greer. (to Kitty) Roger's my new associate. Top of his  class at Michigan Law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty smiles at Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read Eddie's Chase Manhattan  Bombing summation in the Leftist Law  anthology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Eddie told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie clears his throat. Kitty smiles some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My skip-trace turned up two Cecil  Stipes. One's in Butte, Montana.  Other's at Riverhead Veterans  Psychiatric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take odds on Cecil Number Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'd this guy do? Snitch off a  dealer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) Murder witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing a murder case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hasn't been that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty disagrees. She starts counting the years, to hersel on her fingers. Before she can run out of fingers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stipe was just one of four  eyewitnesses who came forward, Kitty.  Y'oughta start looking for the  others...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, I'm not working on this case.  You boys have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have business back on Planet Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme guess. Some corporate V.P.'s  banging his secretary over lunch and  you have to focus your camera and  plug in your little tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats getting paid in twenties by  slimedogs selling angel dust to high  school seniors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty, where exactly do you place  the microphone to catch the most  incriminating moans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger is trying to disappear behind his espresso cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just which Constitutional amendment  protects our right to peddle PCP?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. You've blown your chance  to participate in this case, Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kicking myself, Eddie... Right  out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She briskly exits the coffeehouse. Eddie turns to Roger. Wearing a little grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gray edifice just outside a blue-collar Long Island tow As Eddie and Roger ENTER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to gently pressure a guy  like this to test whether he'll keep  it together on the stand...

dialogues.speaker: CECIL STIPE
dialogues.text: Hollow-eyed, tousle-haired, late-30s. In pajama bottoms a an olive-drab t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Berger said you g-guys needed to  talk to me...?

dialogues.speaker: THE DAYROOM
dialogues.text: Depressing in proportion to the attempts to make it cheer Eddie and Roger sit at a round wooden table we last saw i nursery school. As he pulls out a chair, for a wary Stipe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'lo, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See-cil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See-cil. I'm Eddie Dowd, this is  Roger Baron. We're lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stipe looks at Roger. Then at Eddie. To Eddie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a l-lawyer? (beat) I... I haven't had my meds, or m-my  vital signs t-taken yet. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Stipe. A young man named Jimmy  Chin was shot to death eight years  ago, in Chinatown. Do you remember  talking to the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, then) That guy they arrested -- he was the  wrong g-guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil, we want to reopen the case,  and we can't without your testimony.  I want to use what you have to say  so badly -- but I must add, my friend,  that I think you're fucking full of  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger winces: this is "gentle pressure"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what Eddie wants to say is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! They g-got the wrong guy! I saw  it! The killer wasn't Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Chinese people have this energy  field that vibrates at a particular  frequency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Roger trade glances. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Cecil... What's all this about  the Kennedy assassination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stipe's voice goes hollow. He should've known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from the Company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He anxiously peers past the lawyers -- as though looking a hospital orderly, as though looking for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) CIA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone. (sarcastic) I suppose you don't know the phone  company killed Kennedy because he  was trying to b-break it up -- and  they'll never let that happen. They  control everything: what you say in  the mouthpiece is never exactly what  comes out the other end, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone company was broken up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with muted contempt) And you b-believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Cecil. (places his hand over  Stipe's) Are you what heroes are made of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stipe looks down at Eddie's hand, touching his own. Waits for a lethal bolt of electricity. But nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did two tours in 'Nam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now we're going to take an  affadavit from you, but only  concerning the facts of the Chinatown  shooting. We honestly don't give a  shit about the Kennedy assassination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stipe considers whether Eddie and Roger might be on the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you willing to testify that the  man you saw shoot Jimmy Chin was not  the man the cops arrested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They g-got the wrong g-guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the D.A. hears I filed the writ,  he'll send someone here, maybe  claiming to be a journalist. That  person will ask you lots of questions.  Just be truthful, Cecil, okay? To  all of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always t-tell the truth. (sad smile) That's why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No jury. CECIL STIPE on the stand. Hair freshly cut, bear trimmed. In a suit no worse than Eddie's best. Eddie speaks softly, so as not to excite the mental patie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You told the Desk Sergeant you  were certain Mr. Kim wasn't the  killer? (Stipe nods) You left your telephone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the police make any attempt to  phone you, to follow up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, s-sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Stipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie rejoins Roger at the defense table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rabin? You may cross-examine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assistant D.A. DEAN RABIN, 30, jumps up -- alert and vigi as though he were the bodyguard of Justice herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Stipe, for how long have you  been a patient at the Riverhead  Veterans Psychiatric Hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlapping, Eddie leaps up, ROARS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection, your Honor! The fact that  the witness is currently a patient  is immaterial!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Mr. Stipe, how long have  you resided at the Riverhead Veterans --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rabin, you're out of line. The  question is stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But so, unfortunately, is Stipe: his whole body twitches. Now Rabin moves in for the kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Stipe: you're under oath to tell  the truth and nothing but the truth.  Who killed President Kennedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Objection! Irrelevant! The witness  is not an expert in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Your Honor, the question relates  directly to the witness's bail-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping; tremulous) I'd l-like to answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rabin has no right to --

dialogues.speaker: STIPE
dialogues.text: He's answering. But, given the din of the lawyers' battle he can't be heard. Until the Judge POUNDS his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee... H-Harvey... Oswald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To mouth this hideous lie has taxed all Stipe's strength self-control. In mid-argument, Eddie stops shouting. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's left sheepishly smiling at the Judge, who's wonderin what the hell that was about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu is escorted along the tier by TWO C.O.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter the two C.O.s, with SHU. EDDIE and ROGER wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu, the judge has ordered a retrial  in the Chinatown murder case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu's lips move. No sound emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can prove reasonable doubt on  your imprisonment eight years ago,  we feel sure the D.A. will reduce  the charge in Lindeman's death. You  may get out of here much sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Shu is standing, breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I -- have to be in the courtroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie knows that Shu isn't eager to relive the last trial

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State won't want to retry an  eight-year-old case... At the pre- trial conference, an offer'll be  made. Odds are we'll cut some kinda  deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger is searching Shu's face for a ray of hope. Instead hears, constricted:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I can't pay you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) That's okay, Shu. We're not billing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes Shu even more uncomfortable. His eyes bore int Eddie's, searching for an answer. Finally Eddie supplies it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done enough time, Shu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu holds Eddie's gaze for a beat. Then he nods. And then without expression, he backs out of the Conference Room.

dialogues.speaker: X-RAY POSITIVE
dialogues.text: As we contemplate a man's shattered skull we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the evidence, the bullet,  the wound, the powder burns, Shu's  gun -- they're a perfect match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie sits at his desk, across from Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. The cops tell the eyewitnesses,  "Don't doubt your ID, we got 'em  dead on the gun." Meantime they tell  their ballistics expert, "Hey, it's  cool -- three people saw the guy  fire the gun." It's a game, man. And  you know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eddie continues, Roger queasily flips through a stack forensic exhibits. We SEE x-ray positives of Jimmy Chin's skull, prints of microscopic autopsy slides...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the eight years since the first  trial, advances in forensic ballistics  analysis will enable us to piss on  the evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone starts RINGING. Now the door swings open -- it's KITTY. As she casually s off her overcoat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the prosecution's three original  eyewitnesses, one's dead, one's moved  to Montreal and won't budge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitty catches Roger watching her with a look of pleasant  surprise. With a little smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You getting this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits) But they've still got Laura Gordon --  and she was the closest, about 20  feet from the killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie appears untroubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, maybe she saw the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls a joint from the desk drawer and lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Have to"? No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a hit. Then turns to Kitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start looking into the Joe Boys --  who assigned the hits in 1980, what  rank generally did the hits... (pointedly) Your extensive law enforcement  contacts should be of some use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Roger) I was never politically correct enough  for Comrade Dowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone starts RINGING again. Shouting through the wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No result. So Eddie picks up, as Kitty and Roger continue TALKING, in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie grinds out his joint. Signals his colleagues to shu up. His customary braggadocio giving way to bafflement:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put him through. (then) Speaking. (listens, then) Sure. Fine. See you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Donald Reynard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger has heard of Reynard. With a trace of incredulity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manhattan D.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Central Park South. Where Manhattan's oligarchs go to  stay hungry. Several generations of WASPs stride in and o attache cases in their left hands, racquets in their righ EDDIE hurriedly enters this sanctum of health and wealth, too self-conscious to notice the startled WASPs noticing  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a Rare Book Room ambience. A MAITRE D' steers an edg Eddie past POWER BROKERS who stop brokering, briefly, to  gape at this bizarre interloper. Excepting one self-absor MAGNATE who pontificates on the trade gap at FOUR REPORTE Eddie is delivered to a table in the center of the room.  Settled here, sipping a scotch, is Manhattan D.A. DONALD  REYNARD: mid-40s, sharp-featured, soigne. At Reynard's el sits Dean Rabin. Wearing a vindictive little grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Reynard...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head bowed, Eddie awkwardly thrusts out a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward T. Dowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking) Don Reynard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers Eddie a seat. Indicates the human terrier at hi side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you know Dean Rabin, one  of my Assistant D.A.s. Dean generally  handles nuisance cases like the...  what's the man's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu Kai Kim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't remember this, but in '72  I was one of several prosecutors  assigned to the Black Panther-Police  Shootout. (laughs) We had a whole team, and you walked  into court by yourself and kicked  our collective butt. (beat) So what've you been up to since then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This and that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My staff tells me it's been mostly  drug pushers... I said that can't be  the same Edward Dowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) It's in the area of narcotics, Mr.  Reynard, that the government tramples  on the Fourth Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not drag the Constitution into  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabin can contain himself no longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dowd, you used the testimony of  a paranoid schizophrenic to overturn  a murder conviction that had stood  unchallenged for eight years. Now we  don't intend to sit back and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynard holds up a palm, silencing Rabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you did was very cynical. I'm  annoyed with you, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly a supreme understatement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I've ruined your day,  Mr. Reynard. But my client's had a  rough eight years behind bars and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your client is guilty. Don't dick  around with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabin glows. He's getting revenge, albeit vicariously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the Seventies I spent years  putting away gangsters in a Colombian  syndicate called "the Ochoa". These  guys are very dangerous, Ed. When I  hear that a small-time dope lawyer  is conniving to spring one of these  guys, I see red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have that checked, Mr. Reynard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynard is not amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now maybe you got this case reopened  because you see yourself as a thorn  in society's side, or you want to  walk into any restaurant in Chinatown  and get free dumplings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you implying that my motives are  less than sincere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but that's not the issue. What's  on your wish list, Ed? Pleading Kim  out to first degree man on both  homicides, with an agreed sentence  of 15 to life running concurrent?  Come on... What're you looking for  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I looking for? You're the  one talking deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday's the drop-dead date on the  offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't bullshit me, Mr. Reynard.  You've got witness problems, you've  got proof problems...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my only problem, Ed. What  does it take to make you go away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie doesn't have to ponder long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8-1/3 on both counts to run  concurrent, and credit for time  served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynard pretends to do some calculations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see: He'd walk out next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We reconvict, your man's looking at  25 years on two counts, served  consecutively. So what I'd like to  ask, Ed, is: Are you joking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I never joke about waiving a client's  Sixth Amendment right to trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pissing me off again, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're very tense, Mr.  Reynard. Y'oughta take a week off,  fly the wife and kids to Oahu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie turns. As he lopes away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget: after Friday, no deal.

dialogues.speaker: A REPORTER
dialogues.text: at the Trade Gap table sniffs a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie waits for the elevator. And HEARS a confidential:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... Len Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you've wriggled up  Reynard's ass... What gives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a reporter...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daily News.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for his press card. The elevator arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie boards. Slow enough that the Reporter has time to f him in. The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it opens; Eddie and the Reporter step out. The Reporte madly scribbles notes as Eddie declaims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not saying there was a conspiracy.  Law enforcement is too disorganized  for that... No, I suspect sloth was  the culprit -- lassitude... My client  made a convenient patsy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stride past CAMERA, Eddie just warming up, as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this hour, the espresso has given way to red wine. KIT EDDIE, ROGER and assorted West Village characters have ta over a table in the middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Edward C. Dowd, retained to defend  Mr. Kim, has disclosed that a witness  will corroborate Mr. Kim's alibi"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger reads from the Daily News -- everyone at the table a copy. On an inner page is a file photo of Eddie under t headline "Stunning Revelations in 'Wrong Man' Murder Case

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I embellished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dowd also reports that his team of  private investigators..."?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I embroidered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...are close to naming the man they  believe actually killed Jimmy Chin"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger gives Eddie a thin smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulda told the one about Shu being  the bastard child of Mother Theresa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles back) Saving it for the Sunday Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stands, stretches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm heading home -- get some sleep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eddie starts north, a STREET DEALER calls from the sha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Eddie... Loose joints? Buy one,  get one free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get 'em all free.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHERIDAN SQUARE
dialogues.text: Eddie crosses Seventh Avenue. Pulls out his keys, to let  himself into his building. OS, hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN stands, silhouetted, at the top of the subway stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare a quarter?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: reaches back into his pocket. And gets RAKED across the j with a short length of PIPE.

dialogues.speaker: HIS ASSAILANT
dialogues.text: is a muscular PUNK in a black sleeveless t-shirt. Two bla teardrops tattooed on his cheek. In a WHISPER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Race traitor. Gook lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Punk flings a stunned Eddie halfway down the stairs, continue the beating out of plain sight. On the landing, men bob back and forth, drunken dance partners -- -- and then Eddie manages to grab the Punk's face, squeez it with his ebbing strength, SMUDGING the TEARDROPS.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: puzzles, for an instant, at the smeared "tattoos".

dialogues.speaker: THE PUNK
dialogues.text: senses something's awry. In his eyes, a flicker of panic.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: Then the Punk's eyes go cold again as he smashes Eddie's  head against the tile. As Eddie collapses:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enemy of the Aryan People.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punctuated with a kick of his combat boots. Eddie curls u to protect himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commie. Faggot. Motherfucker. Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasps) -- Only half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For this, Eddie gets another kick. Then the ultimatum, to as a "Confucious say" joke:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aryan Warriors say: If the Chink  goes to trial, you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie groans, his eyes roll back. FADE to BLACK. While th SCREEN stays BLACK, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my humble opinion, Mr. Dowd, you  opened a Pandora's box of ugly shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDDIE, in the Detective Bullpen -- ice pack pressed to hi bruised jaw -- leafs through a mugbook. ROGER, beside him addresses a DETECTIVE, across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Eddie deserved this. I guess  rape victims want to get laid at  gunpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Eddie could care less. Indicating the mugbook:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all the known Aryan Warriors  in New York?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BOOK
dialogues.text: Mugshots and descriptions, four to a page. Several subjec sport the teardrop tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every last delightful one.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE
dialogues.text: Eddie stops paging. Squints.

dialogues.speaker: A MUGSHOT
dialogues.text: of the Punk. Sure enough, no teardrops on his face. His n CHUCKIE ROEDER. Eddie's HANDS enter FRAME. His fingertips still smudged w black ink, from Roeder's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Eddie studies the photo, his fingertips. Abruptly shuts t mugbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'don't mind, I'll look some more  tomorrow. Starting to see double.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they emerge, Roger grips Eddie's upper arm, to steady  him. Quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Chuckie Roeder. But  something's very weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You found his mugshot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They round the corner. In b.g. is the County Coroner's Of official AMBULANCES are double-parked in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tears... they weren't real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger gives Eddie a questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we TIGHTEN on Eddie's wheezing RIVIERA we HEAR, OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe we're going to talk  to a bunch of Nazis. At night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only think they're Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger drives. Eddie, in the passenger seat, massages his  swollen jaw. In his free hand are scribbled directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just frightened, fucked-up  losers that prison fucked up worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense, snaps) I didn't ask for a closing argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no one else to talk to. The  tattoos were phony!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So an upstanding member of the Aryan  Warriors wouldn't paint them on.  They take those teardrops seriously --  they're badges of courage, of honor.  Only their most vicious killer elite  get to wear them...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel much better now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Clyde Gruner sold these guys a  pound of crystal meth at cost. We're  Clyde's buddies, it's cool. (checks the directions) Next exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A desolate, sub-working-class-outpost on Staten Island. Eddie KNOCKS on a door. Roger waits with trepidation. The door is answered by:

dialogues.speaker: A BOY
dialogues.text: Towheaded, in pajamas. No more than eight years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there. Is your daddy home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little boy GIGGLES, then leads Eddie and Roger throug nightmare LIVING ROOM strewn with pizza cartons, shotgun  shells and dogshit. A MAC-10 submachine gun is propped in corner. In another corner, an old b&w TV. Flickering acro the screen: a rerun of "Love, American Style." TWO ARYAN  WARRIORS were slumped in front of it, swigging generic be while ogling the '60s bikini queens. Now they sit up stra and reach for the guns as the lawyers pass, into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little boy wraps his arms around a pair of legs. ANGL UP on a young man whose face is marred by a single teardr tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a friend of Clyde Gruner's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls are decorated with white power posters, portrai of Hitler and Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know who you are. You're the race  traitor who's defending the gook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S. we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got balls coming here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Roger turn. Behind them another Aryan Warrior h materialized. Chewing a Slim Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We respect balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Chuckie Roeder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck? Rhymes with suck? (cackles, then) Chuckie Roeder is no longer a comrade  in the resurrection of our nation.  We expelled that faggot junkie last  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Roger trade glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where he can be found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanging with his tongue out and a  sign around his neck says "I Betrayed  My Race" along with the rest of  society's scum, on the Great Day of  the Rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... prior to the Great Day of the  Rope, where can Chuckie be found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mixing with mongrel races.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- A job? An address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teardrop doesn't answer. Hoping to help him out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art supplies, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teardrop shoots a look at Slim Jim. If looks could kill,  Slim Jim's brains would be decorating the walls. Teardrop turns back to Eddie and Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead Eddie steps forward, in Teardrop's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man jumped me tonight. He said he  was an Aryan Warrior, and you're  saying he wasn't. I have to hear it  really clear: You guys weren't behind  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very slowly, so Eddie gets it straight:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we were, you wouldn't be standing  here, asking.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Route 9, North. An excited Roger drives, a little wildly, the empty road. Eddie stares out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER is asleep, in the back seat of the Riviera. PAN TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the main gate, that isn't open  yet. Eddie stands still, head bowed,  hands clasped behind his back. A  supplicant. Waiting to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Shu are separated by a plexiglass pane. They ta over telephones. Shu strives to remain impassive as he HE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu, the D.A.'s offered us a deal. I  can make a counter-offer I know he'd  accept. You'd be free in four years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu's response:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did that to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie worries his discolored jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Aryan Warrior with black teardrops  painted on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Painted"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't an Aryan Warrior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would a guy would do that?  Paint black teardrops on his face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess he... wanted you to think he  was... somebody he wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... because someone's afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. The truth, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Chinatown. What went down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What went down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You tell me, Shu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I tell you what I don't know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't. So tell me what you do  know -- say it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know shit, man! Goddammit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I know that you're innocent,  Shu -- even if you forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu sucks in a breath. The curses are like stifled sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit... fucking... bitch bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears are spilling down Shu's rock-hard cheeks. Eddie brings his palm up against the plexiglass divider.  He's breathing hard too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu. We take this deal, that's the  end. I don't look for the scumbag  that jumped me, don't get him on the  stand to tell the court who put him  up to it, don't go after the fuck  who put him up to it -- the fuck who  did the crime and let you do the  time... We take this deal, we walk  away without knowing what really  went down, never get a shot at nailing  some guilty bastard's balls to the  wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shu swipes at his face, roughly wiping it dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "No," what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Shu raises his palm. Presses it against the plexiglas where Eddie's palm is. Slowly, emphatically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck the D.A.'s deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry tourists, hyper street vendors, harried locals...  Roasting chicken carcasses, counterfeit merchandise  aggressively hawked, tiny old ladies bent over bins, sque strange fruits... The air a shivaree of piped-in flutes a drums, dissonant mercantile chatter, clogged honking  traffic... On Pell Street we FIND Eddie striding down the sidewalk,  nose in trial transcript. To himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy came east on Pell. He stopped  on the corner to a let a car go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
